Microsoft has released a patch for up to 74 security vulnerabilities, including one for a zero-day bug that is being actively exploited among users. Of the 74 issues, seven are rated critical, 66 important, and one low severity.

This patch is added to another important one with 36 bugs patched in the Microsoft Edge browser based on Chromium on April 28, 2022, so Microsoft has tried in just two weeks to clean its ecosystem as much as possible against all kinds of threats .

CVE-2022-26925, the main vulnerability

These vulnerabilities include 24 remote code execution (RCE), 21 privilege escalation, 17 information disclosure and six denial of service vulnerabilitiesamong other.

Informatic security

The main one of the fixed bugs is CVE-2022-26925a spoofing vulnerability that affects LSA Authentication, the parts of the Local Security Authority (LSA) that applications can use to authenticate and log in users to the local system.

This vulnerability, which is actively exploited, allows an attacker to authenticate as approved users as part of an NTLM (New Technology LAN Manager) relay attackallowing threat actors to gain access to hashes of authentication protocols.

While all servers are affected, domain controllers should be a priority for protection as, once exploited, they provide high-level access privileges, often known as ‘the keys to the kingdom‘.

Other big security fixes

Microsoft recently mitigated a vulnerability (CVE-2022-29972) in the Azure Data Factory and Azure Synapse pipelines. The vulnerability was specific to the third-party Open Database Connectivity (ODBC) driver used to connect to Amazon Redshift in those pipelines. The vulnerability could have allowed an attacker to perform remote command execution through the IR infrastructure without being limited to a single tenant.

security threats

Administrators working with mixed Windows/Linux/Unix environments are also advised to patch quickly CVE-2022-26937, an unauthenticated remote code execution in the Windows Network File System (NFS) service. These types of vulnerabilities will potentially attract ransomware attackers as they could lead to the type of critical data exposure that is often part of a ransom attempt.
